awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Phylogenomics and evolutionary history of the anaerobic fungal group, Neocallimastigomycota
awd_abstract_narration:
The anaerobic gut fungi differ from all other groups of fungi in two ways: they grow in the absence of oxygen, and they grow in a restricted habitat (the rumen and alimentary tract of plant eating animals). They evolved hundreds of millions of years ago and represent one of the oldest fungal groups, yet their evolutionary history is unclear. Specifically, the exact relationship between anaerobic fungi and other fungal groups, as well as the timing and sequence of events that lead to their localization to a gut habitat, remains unclear. Further, it is not exactly known how the gut habitat has affected their genomes and evolution. This project will tackle these questions by sequencing the genomes of a large, diverse collection of anaerobic gut fungi, and analyzing the data produced using a wide range of computational procedures. The proposed efforts will lead to significant advances in the understanding of the history of this peculiar group of fungi and factors driving their evolution. Further, the data obtained would be of extreme interest to a broader group of scientists working in the areas of biofuel research, animal nutrition, and molecular biology of fungi.  The project will engage multiple high school and undergraduate students in research, with special effort to engage minority (especially Native American) students to advance the participation of underrepresented groups in science, technology, and math disciplines. 
 
Overall research progress on anaerobic fungi has been slow, and sequencing of anaerobic gut fungi (AGF) genomes has been hampered by their extremely high adenine-thymine content and the proliferation of intergenic repeats in their genomes. This project will utilize a new approach that combines multiple sequencing technologies to sequence the genomes and transcriptomes of a large and diverse collection of anaerobic fungal isolates. This research will utilize the data generated to conduct an extensive phylogenomic analysis, aiming to resolve their evolutionary history within the fungal tree of life, correlate the timing of AGF diversification events to the evolution of their herbivorous hosts, resolve the diversification pattern of anaerobic fungal genera, and investigate the impact of the unique habitat and evolutionary trajectory on their genomic architecture.

por.por_cntn:
The project examined the ecology, diversity and evolution of a specific group of fungi (The Neocallimastigomycota). The Neocallimastigomycota are unique amongst fungi in many ways: First they are only encountered in the rumen and alimentary tract of herbivores. Second they are very oxygen sensitive and die from air exposure. Third they are very efficient in breaking down plant material into simple sugars. Indeed, they form a symbiotic association with their host, where the host provides shelter and an return, they aid in the degradation of food materials ingested by the host into simpler soluble sugars for the host?s benefits.

The project aimed to address a puzzling question: How can the Neocallimastigomycota, members of the kingdom fungi that evolved a billion years ago, be only present in the gut of animals that have evolved 10-50 million years ago? Specifically, we wanted to understand: 1. How related this special group of fungi is to other known free living and oxygen tolerant fungal lineages?  Where did the Neocallimastigomycota ancestor reside before the evolution of herbivorous animals? When was the symbiotic relationship between the fungus and the animal established? And what events faciliatated the establishment of this symbiotic relationship?

The project achieved all these goals. We leaned heavily on genomic sequencing and genomic data analysis for evolutionary purposes (a discipline called Phylogenomics) to achieve such goals. First, we identified the position and evolutionary history of the Neocalliamstigomycota in the broader fungal tree of life, and showed that they are most closely related to a group of fungi called Chytrids. Second, we timed the evolution of this group around and determined that it evolved 65 million years ago. This is a similar time to the evolution of herbivory in mammals and evolution of grasses. As such, it seems that both process (Neocallimastigomycota evolution and evolution of herbivory in mammals) were closely intertwined. Third, we inferred that the ancestors of these fungi had very limited capacity to degrade complex plant materials (e.g. cellulose and hemicellulose). More importantly, we determined that the Neocallimstigomycota have evolved into efficient degrader of plant material from such an ancestor by freely borrowing genes that enables them to do so from single cell microbes (Bacteria and Archaea, Image 1). This process is called cross kingdom horizontal gene transfer. We also identified the potential microbial donors from which these genes were borrowed.

In addition, as part of our overall assessment of the diversity of the Neocallimastigomycota, we identified, isolated, characterized, and named many new Neocallimastigomycoata fungal isolates that are new to science (Image 2). We also developed new ways to identify what genera of Neocallimastigomycota are present in a specific animal without the need for cumbersome isolation process (Image 3). Our work has greatly expanded the known genera and species of the Neocallimsatigomycota. We finally determined that the animal lifestyle dictates what type of Neocallimstigomycota genera resides in its digestive system. The wild, non-domesticated herbivores appear to harbor very distinct types of Neocallimstigomycota, many of which are completely new to science.
